--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "JT" <skybro77@...> wrote:
>
> I just started =
reading on Hierarchical Bayesian Optimization
> Algorithm. Has any one benc=
hmarked it with Neat or HyperNeat?
>

It's quite a different approach than =
NEAT and probably trying to
address a different set of issues.  In that sen=
se, it's potentially
even compatible with NEAT.  NEAT tries to complexify a=
nd preserve
diversity while hBOA (or any EDA) tries to discover the optimal=

variation in the genes.  

I have not seen any direct comparison on any ta=
sk, though one may
exist.  I would also not be surprised if someone somewhe=
re has or will
try to combine them.

One way to think about BOA, which is n=
ot the way it's usually
described, is as a kind of special indirect encodin=
g, wherein the
Bayesian network that is form is a kind of indirect encoding=
 for a
population.  In other words, it embodies certain dependencies and
re=
lationships the way an indirect encoding like HyperNEAT would. 
However, th=
e difference is that BOA tries to explicitly figure out the
best relationsh=
ips based on the correlations in the genes in the
current population, where=
as HyperNEAT and most other indirect
encodings search implicitly.   However=
, searching explicitly is not
necessarily better because it means you are a=
ssuming that early
explicit correlations are not spurious or misleading, wh=
ich, in a
really complex domain, they probably are.  Not to say that it is =
not
very powerful in some cases.

ken
